unnormalised: Environmental News: Mumbai's Waste Woes Getting a Tech Boost!
normalised: Environmental News: Mumbai's Waste Woes Getting a Tech Boost!

unnormalised: Hey everyone, guess what? Mumbai's garbage problem, which honestly, feels like a never-ending Bollywood drama, is finally getting a high-tech intervention! The BMC (Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation) is teaming up with IIT Bombay to pilot AI-powered waste segregation systems across the city.
normalised: Hey everyone, guess what? Mumbai's garbage problem, which honestly, feels like a never-ending Bollywood drama, is finally getting a high-tech intervention! The B M C (Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation) is teaming up with I I T Bombay to pilot A I-powered waste segregation systems across the city.

unnormalised: Imagine fewer overflowing bins and more recycling! The project aims to automatically sort waste at source, identifying materials like plastic, paper, and glass using image recognition. No more relying solely on the hard-working bhaiyyas and didis to manually sift through everything.
normalised: Imagine fewer overflowing bins and more recycling! The project aims to automatically sort waste at source, identifying materials like plastic, paper, and glass using image recognition. No more relying solely on the hard-working bhaiyyas and didis to manually sift through everything.

unnormalised: Initially, the pilot will cover areas like Bandra and Andheri, processing roughly 5 tonnes of waste daily. The BMC hopes this initiative will boost recycling rates by at least 30% and drastically reduce the amount of waste going to the Deonar dumping ground, which, let's face it, is a disaster zone.
normalised: Initially, the pilot will cover areas like Bandra and Andheri, processing roughly five tonnes of waste daily. The B M C hopes this initiative will boost recycling rates by at least thirty percent and drastically reduce the amount of waste going to the Deonar dumping ground, which, let's face it, is a disaster zone.

unnormalised: Early results are promising, and if successful, the plan is to roll out this technology across all 24 wards of Mumbai. Maybe, just maybe, this will finally be a happy ending to our waste management saga!
normalised: Early results are promising, and if successful, the plan is to roll out this technology across all twenty four wards of Mumbai. Maybe, just maybe, this will finally be a happy ending to our waste management saga!
